data.name: Save Private Brain
data.description:
Javascript programmers are quite lazy. They don't like the long bureaucratic syntax constructions inherent for strongly typed static languages, such as Java or C#. Perhaps that's why the encapsulation mechanism in JS implemented... quite frivolously. We don't need to write these annoying access modifiers, instead, within the team or a whole community we agree about rules for naming private properties(like starting with underscore) and never touch them without a permission. And it works well while your teammates are disciplined. But if someone starts to behave saucily - the problems begin. Even worse when you call or email that person and get one answer: -BRAAAINS!

Okay, we'll deal with those fella later, but right now we need to protect our code from invasion.
As a starting point you have two predefined classes `User` and `Zombie`. You cannot override them or modify their prototypes, however you also have their instances `ashWilliams` and `evilAsh` respectively, free for manipulations. `evilAsh` object has a method `gobbleBrains()` which invades our "private"(in fact not) property.

Your goal is to prevent `evilAsh` from modifying his own `_stomach` and `ashWilliams`'s `_brains` property, while the other user `annieKnowby` must retain the access to other properties not interesting to evil Ash.

If you want go further try not only to prohibit `evilAsh` from changing his stomach, but instead feed him with `bullets` value. This will not affect the tests, but you will be rewarded for your bravery with a secret message.

Keep in mind that you need to deal with instances, not classes, you also shouldn't worry about Annie, she's in safe place. Only about Ash.

Placing your code inside a function is not necessary, you can write in a plain way.
